comments.commentBody: Because the ones who should be punished run everhything inclluding Obama.

The only panel which should matter is the U.S. voter. It is we who have an interest in maintaining 3 branches of government with checks and balances. That the CIA would go after the staff members of a Senate committee is truly appalling. It means they thought they knew better than the constitution, how our business is to be done. Last I checked, that would require the rest of us voting.

Why is no one prosecuted for anything during the Obama administration?

This case draws to mind unfortunate parallels with the Eric Garner situation. In both, a respected and powerful organization engaged in gross malfeasance. The basic facts were incontrovertible. In both, the chief executive responsible for overseeing the organization refused to take sides or to call out the organization as corrupt.

Most importantly, in both cases we have little to no recourse and the organizations are likely to continue doing exactly what they've been doing.
The Governor had no say in the decision regarding the pipeline - it was pushed through by the federal government/FERC.
Yes, you could say that New York is outsourcing its pollution.  No issue is as black and white as it seems.

And that pipeline is probably what feathered his nest sufficiently so he could prevent the southern tier from becoming like North Dakota; dangerous, dirty, inhospitable and expensive. It's probably a good thing that rents along the Chemung and Susquehanna rivers won't approach those along the East and Hudson, as they do in the Bakken. I'm certain, however, that when economic pressures rise enough, this decision will be "reconsidered" and reversed as easily as it was made. For now, though, New Yorkers win.
Now for the other side of the coin, which has the governor's likeness on both heads and tails:
There is NO economic, much the less societal, justification or advantage for expanding gambling in this manner. The industry is in steep decline in the region and the new casinos will not draw a significant new customer base, it will just expand the fleecing of those least able to afford it, and water down the already declining fortunes of established venues. However, as the lynch pin or fulcrum of all the associated investment and development, Cuomo has what I'd describe as a Wynn-Wynn scenario. This is classic NY politics writ large. The connections, contributions and facilitation will likely not be revealed for decades.
Andy may not be despoiling Mother Nature at the moment, but he's besmirching the legacy of his father, Mario, who was a class act. It's a pity he didn't learn more than raw politics at his father's knee.
Interesting that a $700 million, 125 mile pipeline was just approved to bring gas from Pennsylvania to New York.  So New York will get its gas anyway.

How scary does new Cuba sound?
With new ideas it does abound,
Casinos, mob run,
Were never great fun,
It's good they're no longer around.

Henry is totally correct in asking where are the Republicans, indeed? I thought "privacy against government intrusion" was a basic conservative value?
Why doesn't this kind of intrusion upset Republicans?
Let's not forget how Florida and the US House voted on Terri Schiavo. That's how stupid things were in those days.

RVDGinUpstateNY: No need to be so defensive. Linda's comment was not against same-sex marriage. She poses a perfectly valid question: if "connecting with another human being by sharing, listening, and showing vulnerabilities can lead to compromise," could that be used to promote illiberal, narrow-minded thinking?

Sounds like you don't buy gas much.  Or, heating oil for your house, or even a house itself, or a laptop computer (with similar power), or.....  Also, sounds like you aren't hiring workers for particular jobs.
I like when couples exchange gifts.  Savings and a great gift in one.

I agree with you for the most part Les.

First, there is a derogatory term for professor ratings (edutainment), in other words, the professor that is the most entertaining is the one who is rated the highest. This does not necessarily mean that they were the most effective. The best thing that ever happened to me in college was when a professor slapped me up side the head (metaphorically) and told me i could do better. I'm sure in my infinite 20-year old wisdom I found it worthwhile to excoriate him come ratings time...but he was right. The point is that ratings can be manipulated.

On research. The best professors relate their research to the classroom. In fact, I challenge students to take my current ideas and make them better. Universities have two missions: knowledge creation and knowledge dissemination. Remove the former, you won't long have the latter. But both are inseparably intertwined.

On ratings. if you want to find a great college I suggest you take your kids on the road. Sit in on a class. Talk to other students. Talk to your friends. Drop by the professor's office (surprisingly few do). At my university there are super-smart people with incredible ideas who are passionate about young people (I wish I could take their classes!). Find them! You can try to quantify this if you wish, but I suggest you go find out for yourself. That's what I plan to do with my children. And if you sense the professor isn't doing his or her job, vote with your wallet.

The education is an afterthought if it's an afterthought to the student. How many kids pay all that money and then spend their time in partying and binge drinking? They're paying for the piece of paper and that's what they're getting. The education is available as well for those who want it, but not all of them do.

No matter where you go, you get out of college what you put into it.
No.  Big data is irrelevant.  This is a problem of too many variables.

Well, that's scary. First, DoE bureaucrats rate colleges. Then, they punish the students in them if the colleges don't meet their criteria.

Look at what the feds have done to colleges already. You wish to extend that influence even further?
Never happen.  And the notion of going to school that matches your character (which is somehow political or religious) is really offensive.  Echo chambers are not educational.

That seems almost refreshing, given the number of questionably useful degrees being issued.  We have enough "marine biologists" to staff the world.  We have way too much "critical ___ analysis" majors.  They will end up in Starbucks, serving coffee.

Political stunt.  Problem=kids having federal money dangled in front of them with no idea of the impact of debt or the utility of the courses they take.  Solution=make up another federal program that employes the public policy or education majors.
Tsk, tsk. You are a college student and yet can't be bothered to conduct simple research to back up your position?
Quite luxuriously.
Which in turn would mean that only 25 colleges in the U.S. would be able to make payroll.  Most colleges would be out of business within six months.
Bad news: it is the students of these tenured radicals who run DoE.
Yes, a problem that the most sophisticated theorists would struggle with (or, more likely, they would point out the futility of proceeding down that road).  And we give it to DoE.
Your assuming robots goals would be in humanity best intrest. If it is it will be much better, however if Ai's goal becomes to destroy humanity or anything like that will have no chance.

Well I for one would be ecstatic if we could outsource government to robots. Robots would be analytical, objective, calculating, and not so hell bent on ideology, bias, ignorance, naivete, stupidity and make the tough decisions some leaders do not have the stomach for. Robots ruling us would do better for the middle class than what we currently have. If robots ruled us, they'd probably think robots actually hurt jobs and would hold back or prohibit development to allow society to slowly adjust.

Like Samaranch before him, Blatter shows us a good example of how easily power can be abused in sports bureaucracy. There is lack of transparency, lack of accountability and a convenient pact between the autocrat and Third World FIFA aparatchiks who are delighted to have their per diems covered.

It is obvious that Blatter will hang on for dear life and that his calculation is to outstay the critics. Given that FIFA is such a money maker, he can easily buy off the competitors and challengers. The only solution is to dissolve the entire corrupt edifice and start from the scratch.
The erasable Internet will not be truly erasable, it will simply make information a little harder to come by.

I think the erasable internet will quickly enable a new set of unintended consequences. A contributor to bad behavior is the ability to hide one's identity on the web. Imagine the volume of threats, hazing and other poisonous behavior when someone thinks he or she can commit such deeds without the chance of getting caught.

alas, mr. Underwood, so many of the GOP have proved they
have no hearts!

He probably didn't not grow up with a lot of conflict in Hawaii and Indonesia. I certainly had a lot more conflict as being a light skinned biracial person growing up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. And at Harvard, the President was probably seen as an "exception." Lastly, there was the convention speech in which he said there is no red or blue America.

Yet what he didn't realize is that there is still an America that resists the idea of a Black man telling them what to do. He tried to make nice with the Republicans but am glad that he finally concluded that it was a lost cause and that he had his own power to make change.

So use that pen, Mr. President. Keep on doin' what you're doin' because you're doin' great!

You are so right that Clinton had a different understanding of politics. Clinton's understanding led to "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" and "Defense of Marriage Act" which have taken 20 years to finally pull down. They led to total unravelling of Glass-Steagall, and the Commodities Futures Trading Commission collapse, which set the stage for the depression the world suffered starting in 2007. They led to a huge increase in poverty because of so-called "welfare reform." I could go on, but you get the idea. Clinton's "triangulation" was a disaster.

Oh yes, and his slap on the back, I'm everyone's friend led to his being vulnerable to right wing obsessiveness and the country's complete focus on his genitals rather than the leadership we sorely needed. Worse, it led to Dubya.

He just did not get it.

The GOP had no intention of working with him for bipartisan solutions to the nations problems, yet he kept at it, even when they made it clear they were going to do everything they could to make him a failed president.

He does not seem to understand politics like Clinton did. He did not know how to schmooze with them, or to backslap them, he seemed to think by being a nice guy, they would cooperate. He finally wakes up to the idea that politics involve conflict with differing ideologies.

I think he got where he is by avoiding conflict. He got along with almost everyone, and had not had to deal with whole assembly of people, that were not going to even try to get along with him.

People who question his nationality, his patriotism, his religion. There is no way he was going to get along with them, but he just did not seem to be able to accept that. I do not think he had ever met so many people in one place, that did not like him, and who were determined to make him fail.

He has to be extraordinary to have survived this rancor, and opprobrium from a collection of some of the most vicious politicians we have ever seen. People who are more interested in personal vendettas, than the well being of the country. And now we are stuck with them for at least the next two years, and probably longer. As one history professor I one had, said, "What we need is a few GOP heart attacks!"
